componenttextpreview: If you look -- we do not give guidance for the next 5 years, but for sure, we are expecting a double digit in the coming years for our nonfuel business. So then you can run the numbers and you will see that obviously in the -- in 3 to 5 years, the contrib
componenttext: If you look -- we do not give guidance for the next 5 years, but for sure, we are expecting a double digit in the coming years for our nonfuel business. So then you can run the numbers and you will see that obviously in the -- in 3 to 5 years, the contribution of the nonfuel business would be much higher than what you have today. And this is what we are playing. This is the aim that we have, it's really to increase the nonfuel business. We are the largest fuel retail player, I'm talking largest convenience store player in the UAE. And this is where is the site for ADNOC Distribution.

headline: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2019
companyname: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC
componenttextpreview: Indeed, Athmane. So just to add on to that. What we've learned from the promotions that the company has run is we've picked lots and lots of useful information about our customers. One piece of it, they like to be rewarded, they like to be -- for their lo
componenttext: Indeed, Athmane. So just to add on to that. What we've learned from the promotions that the company has run is we've picked lots and lots of useful information about our customers. One piece of it, they like to be rewarded, they like to be -- for their loyalty to ADNOC Distribution. Two, we also learned that the 14 of our stores, which are Géant stores, experienced such an uplift in sales and those are really starting to come through now. H1 2019, both quarters, first quarter and second quarter, as I've stated 26.7% year-on-year first half in terms of sales revenue. Profit -- gross profit increasing as well. Basket size increasing as well. What that tells me is the revitalization program, the uplift in the stores, the category management, better category management in introducing fresh foods and the grab-and-go concept. These initiatives are really starting to resonate with our customers. So I'm really excited. At present, we have 14 Géant stores, but the convenience store revitalization that we're going to do, which is part of our 2019 plan and then continues into 2020, the Oasis stores of course, not the Géant, stores but these are now Oasis stores that are going to be revamped look and feel and the overall customer experience will improve significantly. Very excited about what kind of numbers we're going to report back on second half of 2019, but certainly, 2020 as well. So what's important is the initiatives we're -- we've undertaken. We already know from having tested the 14 stores as well as from the loyalty programs and the summer promotions, we're doing initiatives which resonate with our customers. So once again, very positive about what's going to happen second half of the year but also what numbers -- what the numbers tell us in 2020.

componenttextpreview: Yes. So this is a question, I believe, related to the gross profit by segment, Slide #13. So keep in mind that our operating model is twofold. We provide fuel sales only to our strategic customers, civil aviation airlines are not our customers. What we do
componenttext: Yes. So this is a question, I believe, related to the gross profit by segment, Slide #13. So keep in mind that our operating model is twofold. We provide fuel sales only to our strategic customers, civil aviation airlines are not our customers. What we do is only providing -- operating into plane refueling services at multiple airports here in UAE. And this is an illustration of our cost efficiencies. Our costs actually have come down, including in the area of Aviation services, and that is effectively reducing the recovery together plus 8% reported margin that we had on top of these services. However, the impact at EBITDA level is of course relatively marginal because that's where we capture the OpEx savings offsetting the reduced revenue that we get from the services.

componenttext: Okay. Okay. First of all, as far as the overall economy, we're starting to see some green shoots there with an increase in Corporate volumes. Based on our experience, it's a good indication, it's a good lagging indication of how the macroeconomic conditions are developing. So having said that, on top of our expansion that we've explained over the course of the call, I fully expect low single-digit year-on-year growth for the second half of 2019 to combine that with, again, market expansion but as well as our full focus, this customer centricity approach that we're taking out to reward our customers through our loyalty scheme. All said and done, expecting good solid single-digit year-on-year growth for the second half of 2019.

componenttextpreview: Just one follow-up question on the C-store, if I may. I'm just doing some numbers and clearly, you've managed to improve the conversion in terms of dollars per 1,000 liters to around $50 in H1 '19. Can we just get color which is -- I mean on a quarterly b
componenttext: Just one follow-up question on the C-store, if I may. I'm just doing some numbers and clearly, you've managed to improve the conversion in terms of dollars per 1,000 liters to around $50 in H1 '19. Can we just get color which is -- I mean on a quarterly basis Q2 is like 23% year-over-year, which is very solid. Can we just get more color on maybe some trends in terms of when you revitalize the store. And clearly, you understand that you've manage to revitalize more than 50% of the network, how much of an uplift are you seeing in basket size and convergence ratios? This the first part of the question. And the second part, how different is it in terms of conversion between a normal ADNOC Oasis C-store, which was just revitalized, and the Géant, which is the 14 stores that you have, which apparently are doing very well, and recently, the new grab-and-go just fresh bakery? If you can just put things in perspective with some numbers on that, that would be very helpful.

headline: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2019
companyname: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC
componenttextpreview: Yes. Okay. I will try to not disappoint you, Taher. So just on the nonfuel business and the convenience stores. So your first question was what is the impact of revitalizing the C-store prior and after in terms of revenues margin. So obviously, we are see
componenttext: Yes. Okay. I will try to not disappoint you, Taher. So just on the nonfuel business and the convenience stores. So your first question was what is the impact of revitalizing the C-store prior and after in terms of revenues margin. So obviously, we are seeing in the C-store where we had completely changed the look and feel, the assortment, all the products, et cetera, the material increase in our revenues and the profit. So this is the answer. Two, performance, Oasis versus just Géant, we said earlier in Q1 and the Capital Market Day that the Géant stores have a higher profitability because we are using the knowledge of the Géant Group in terms of category management and how we organize the C-stores. But our Oasis stores, which account today for 90% of our convenience stores, we have brought new capabilities, people who are expert in the convenience stores, people coming from large retailer and working on the revitalization of the core business of the C-store, which is Oasis. So we expect good results coming from Oasis because that we have, I would say, revitalizing completely the C-stores. And the upside is, I would say, much higher than what you would have for a store that we have with Géant, obviously. Does it answer your question?

componenttext: Okay. Well, thank you. Thank you all for being here with us today. Just want to reiterate and -- our strategy going forward for this year and also 2020. componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning and good afternoon, everyone. This is Faisal Azmeh of Goldman Sachs and I'd like to welcome you all to ADNOC Distribution's 2019 Second Quarter Results Conference Call. It is my pleasure to host the company's executive management t
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning and good afternoon, everyone. This is Faisal Azmeh of Goldman Sachs and I'd like to welcome you all to ADNOC Distribution's 2019 Second Quarter Results Conference Call. It is my pleasure to host the company's executive management team today. The call will start with management's comments on the quarter and the first half, followed by a Q&A session. 
Without further delay, I'll hand it over now to Athmane Benzerroug, the Chief Investor Relations Officer of ADNOC.

headline: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2019
companyname: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC
componenttextpreview: Yes. Hi, everyone. Good morning and good afternoon. This is Athmane Benzerroug. So I'm pleased to welcome this afternoon Saeed Mubarak Al Rashdi, our Chief Executive Officer; Mohamed Al Hashimi, our new Chief Operating Officer; and Petri Pentti, our Chief
componenttext:
Yes. Hi, everyone. Good morning and good afternoon. This is Athmane Benzerroug. So I'm pleased to welcome this afternoon Saeed Mubarak Al Rashdi, our Chief Executive Officer; Mohamed Al Hashimi, our new Chief Operating Officer; and Petri Pentti, our Chief Financial Officer. The objective of the call is to take you through our second quarter and first half results for 2019. 
We will start with a brief update on our strategy. We will then provide details on the financial performance of the second quarter and the first half of 2019, and finally, move on to the outlook for 2019 and beyond. So we will then answer any questions you might have at the end of this presentation. 
Before handing over to -- the call to Saeed, please allow me to reiterate our cautionary statement regarding forward-looking statements. So this presentation includes forward-looking statements relating to our business, important factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from our expectations [ audited ] in the international offering memorandum related to our IPO and in other investor communications, all of which are available on our website. So I direct everyone to our website to read the full text of this disclaimer and these other materials. 
I now hand it over to Saeed, who will start by presenting the key highlights of the first half.

headline: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2019
companyname: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Athmane, and good morning and good afternoon, everyone. Thank you for joining us today. Please allow me to start first by introducing Mohamed Al Hashimi, our new Chief Operating Officer, who has joined our leadership team to focus on execution
componenttext:
Thank you, Athmane, and good morning and good afternoon, everyone. Thank you for joining us today. Please allow me to start first by introducing Mohamed Al Hashimi, our new Chief Operating Officer, who has joined our leadership team to focus on execution of the company's ambitious growth strategy. 
Mohamed is replacing John Carey, who has recently elected to step down as Deputy CEO, but he will continue in an advisory capacity for the time being. John joined us at a time of our IPO and has provided an excellent [ concept ] and leadership to our business as we successfully completed our listing on Abu Dhabi Securities Exchange. 
I would like to place on record my thanks to John for his dedicated efforts during an important period of the company's growth and evolution. 
Before we go into the first half highlights, I would like to reiterate that safety remains a core value to our business. We continue to enhance and invest in safety solutions. 
So in terms of financial performance, we have delivered a 2.8% increase in EBITDA to USD 404 million in the first of 2019 versus the same period in 2018. Excluding inventory gains, EBITDA grew by 11% to USD 371 million in the first half of 2019, and that is mainly driven by continued cost efficiency improvements across the business and better corporate and nonfuel performance. 
We have also shown continued momentum with the first half of 2019 EBITDA margin, reaching 14.4%, up from the 13.2% during the same period last year. We also made significant progress in our cost savings with OpEx of USD 36 million on like-to-like basis in the first half of 2019. 
During the first half, we added 3 new service stations and 12 new convenience stores to our current footprint. We are on track to deliver on our transformation initiative and growth plans. During the remainder of 2019, we are focused on the acceleration of our domestic growth network expansion particularly in Dubai and the growth of our own nonfuel business to provide superior experience to our customers. We also continue to explore opportunities to grow internationally, including Saudi Arabia and markets that we deliver against our investment criteria of 13% IRR threshold. 
Cost efficiencies also remain a core focus, and we will continue to improve our OpEx and CapEx plans. Finally, we try to continue to deliver strong and sustainable growth while providing attractive returns to our shareholders. This is evidenced by the announcement on April of a significant increase to our dividend confirming our confidence in our growth strategy and future cash flow generation. 
I will now let Mohamed give you an update and more color on our strategy execution.

headline: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2019
companyname: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you, Saeed. I am pleased that on my first call with you, we can show solid progress on our growth strategy. So I met many of you around the time of the IPO back in 2017 as well as our recent Capital Markets Day, both in London and New York. S
componenttext:
Great. Thank you, Saeed. I am pleased that on my first call with you, we can show solid progress on our growth strategy. So I met many of you around the time of the IPO back in 2017 as well as our recent Capital Markets Day, both in London and New York. So just to add a bit of background, I was closely involved in the ADNOC Distribution's IPO process, and I've delivered large-scale projects, transactions and partnerships as Senior Vice President of [ Group's ] Strategic Investments for the ADNOC Group. 
More recently, I was also adviser to the ADNOC Distribution executive committee. This has helped provide me with in-depth knowledge of the ADNOC Distribution business, and more importantly, its plans for growth. ADNOC Distribution remains focused on delivering its ambitious strategy as well as building long-term shareholder value through the next phase of our growth. Now we've delivered strong first half year results with more to come. 
So let me begin by giving you an update on the Retail fuel segment, our first strategic pillar. 
During the Capital Markets Day, we presented a refreshed investment proposition, and we announced key initiatives to be implemented during the course of 2019 and beyond. So in line with earlier guidance that most of our new stations will open towards the end of 2019, I'm pleased to announce that we remain on track to open 20 to 30 new stations across the UAE this year, and we are clearly focused on accelerating our footprint in Dubai. 
So in the first half alone, we've opened 3 new stations in UAE and also pleased to announce that we have just opened 2 additional stations in Dubai this week leading to a total of 6 service stations currently operating in Dubai. So our domestic network expansion track -- target is on track, and we've already identified an in-advance stage of execution on 18 new sites. 
Secondly, on Saudi Arabia, we will provide more color on our expansion plans and operating model during our Q3 results announcement. Our focus at present remains on our home market. So in the second quarter, we launched a number of marketing promotions to address the anticipated lower retail fuel volumes, and we've encouraged our customers to register in our Wallet mobile application towards the enhancement of our overall customer experience. We were pleased to see encouraging results with fuel retail volumes stable in second quarter of 2019 compared to the first quarter of 2019. 
On the Corporate segment, we've achieved 5.5% year-on-year growth in volumes in the first half of 2019. Now this was driven by increased sales of LPG, lubricants as well as base oil. Now we expect this trend in corporate volumes to continue during 2019 following significant government investments in the economy. 
In first half of 2019, we also entered the commercial 100 lb cylinder market in Dubai. Now we've chosen to enter the Dubai LPG market by partnering with established distributors, which now gives us a quick route to market and an effective entry. 
So moving on to nonfuel retail. First half of 2019, we opened 12 new convenience stores across the UAE. Now 10 of these were opened in the second quarter of 2019 at our existing retail sites. At the end of first half 2019, we had a total of 262 convenience stores. Now 14 of these are Géant stores. Our -- the company's convenience stores revitalization programs, which I alluded to yesterday, also offers our customers a significantly improved shopping experience. Pleased to say that this is on track and is contributing to positive convenience store performance. 
Improvements were also seen in gross margins and an overall uplift in the average basket size in the first half of 2019 compared to the first half of 2018. Sales revenue from convenience stores was up by 26.7% year-on-year in first half of 2019. Gross profit increased by 28.9% and the average convenience store basket size increased by 6.8% year-on-year in first half 2019. 
Now this has been achieved through various factors. Improving the look and feel of our stores, better category management adapting to the demand of our customers, and the introduction of fresh grab-and-go concept, positive performance of Géant stores, rewards issued to our customers under the Flex initiative, and an improved customer value proposition through the introduction of promotions supported by in-store marketing. 
So at the end of the second quarter 2019, ADNOC Flex Premium penetration was 15% to 20% on average, in line with what we have seen in the first quarter. 
Now to sum up, we are going to continue our expansion, and we remain absolutely committed to our convenience store revitalization program in order to further improve our overall customer experience. 
So finally, let me give you an update on our cost efficiency initiative, the third pillar of our strategic plan. We have made significant progress in rationalizing our cash OpEx. Pleased to say that we've achieved $36 million in like-for-like OpEx savings in the first half of 2019 mainly driven by cost-optimization initiatives. Now we are on track to achieve around $50 million of OpEx savings in 2019 on a like-for-like basis. 
In terms of capital expenditure, so far we've spent $38 million of CapEx in the first half of 2019. As I've stated, we remain focused on defining a network expansion allocation in the first half of 2019. As also mentioned earlier, our network rollout is scheduled for operational deployment towards the end of this year. In line with that, we expect to accelerate our capital expenditure in the second half of 2019. We maintained our guidance on capital expenditure for the year of up to $300 million to boost our network expansion in the UAE and internationally with 20 to 30 new sites in the UAE, primarily in Dubai to accelerate our convenience store expansion, to continue to significantly improve our customer experience and to invest in our IT infrastructure and digital initiatives. 
So in addition to the savings we have achieved so far, we see more room to achieve further capital expenditure efficiency in building new sites. 
So at this point, I will now hand over to Petri to present the highlights of our financial performance.

headline: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2019
companyname: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC
componenttextpreview: Many thanks, Mohamed, and good morning, good afternoon, everyone. So as Mohamed mentioned, the implementation of our initiatives have resulted in the achievement of positive results in the first half despite the decrease in overall fuel volumes. The first
componenttext:
Many thanks, Mohamed, and good morning, good afternoon, everyone. So as Mohamed mentioned, the implementation of our initiatives have resulted in the achievement of positive results in the first half despite the decrease in overall fuel volumes. The first half revenues reached USD 2.8 billion, down by 6.3% when compared to the first half of 2018. This decline in revenues was mainly driven by lower fuel volumes sold as well as lower pump average prices. To use an example, our 95 gasoline octane average pump prices for the first half of  2019 were 8.5% below first half 2018. Having said that, we saw a continuous improvement in our convenience stores business with an increase in revenues by 26.7% in the first half to USD 107 million driven by the revitalization program that Mohamed was talking about. 
We do see [ green shoot ] in our Corporate business. Volumes are up 5.5% year-on-year driven by increase in LPG and lubricant sales following significant government investments in the UAE economy. Our gross profit reached USD 675 million, down 5% compared to the previous year. The decrease is mainly due to the lower inventory gains in the first half, $33 million versus $58 million in 2018 in our Retail business. 
Meanwhile, we achieved a 10% increase in our nonfuel gross profit mainly coming from the convenience stores in the first half compared to the 2018 period, and this is driven by the improved category management and our fuel rewards program. 
Our gross profit margin has also shown continued momentum and is still at an industrial leading level, reaching 24.1% in the first half of 2019, up from 23.8% last year. And this is driven by lower revenue due to lower pump prices compared with the secured minimum retail margin as per the Ministry of Energy regulations here in UAE. 
Finally, our total EBITDA for the first half reached $404 million, representing an increase of 2.8% year-on-year driven by the continued cost efficiencies, growth in the corporate segment and more dynamic product pricing. We've made significant progress in rationalizing our OpEx and have [ stabilized achieving ] USD 36 million in like-for-like OpEx savings during the first half driven by the cost optimization initiatives. Our cash OpEx declined by 16.5% in the first half compared to first half last year, reaching $282 million. Excluding the inventory gains of $33 million for Q2 '19 and $58 million for the first half 2018, the underlying EBITDA grew by 11% year-on-year in the first half, once again, driven by the cost efficiency improvements across the whole business. 
Finally, we generated strong free cash flow measured as EBITDA minus CapEx. Free cash flow is up by 21% year-on-year to $366 million in the first half driven by also higher EBITDA and lower CapEx. 
Overall, fuel sales volumes were down in first half by 1.7% driven by 3.5% decrease in fuel rate volumes mainly due to increased competition as well as the impact of the longer public holiday in second quarter 2019 compared to the same period last year. 
On the Corporate segment side, volumes increased by 5.5% first half driven by the higher sales of the LPG, lubricant and base oil as stated earlier. And finally, our Aviation segment volumes sold to the strategic customers were marginally up in the first half 2019. 
Looking at the gross profit performance by segment. Gross profit for nonfuel retail mainly convenience stores increased by 10% year-on-year in the first half. This is reflecting our diversification strategy towards nonfuel retail and implementation of the new initiatives to improve customer experience, including a much more focused stores revitalization program as well as the positive contribution from our fuel rewards program. Our fuel retail gross profit decreased in the first half by 8.7% year-on-year. This is driven by the decrease in fuel retail volumes as well as lower inventory gains as stated earlier in the first half 2019. In the Corporate segment, gross profit has increased in the first half by 12.3% and margin has increased from 18.5% to 19.8% on the back of the increase in volumes, better inventory management as well as more dynamic product pricing. 
And finally, our Aviation gross profit has decreased in the first half by 8.7% year-on-year. This is driven by lower Aviation services and civil aviation OpEx recovery under the arrangement we have with the parent company, ADNOC. 
Moving on to EBITDA. Total EBITDA for first half reached $404 million. This is an increase of 2.8% year-on-year. As stated earlier, continued cost efficiencies as well as Corporate segment performance is contributing to this increase together with higher Corporate volumes.
Our fuel and nonfuel retail company EBITDA increased by 0.3% and Corporate segment by 29.4% year-on-year in the first half. Q2 2019 EBITDA growth was driven by Retail segment with an increase in EBITDA margins driven by cost efficiencies despite the lower volumes. Q2 '19 Corporate EBITDA was flat due to lower diesel margins partially offset by cost efficiencies and higher volumes. 
And finally, Aviation EBITDA was flat due to stable volumes and cost efficiencies partially offset by lower aviation services revenue. Excluding the inventory gains realized in the second quarter '19 and during the first half 2018, $33 million and $58 million, respectively, underlying EBITDA increased year-on-year by 11% during the first half. 
And finally, a few comments on our cash position and cash flow during the first half. Net cash generated from operating activities has increased mainly due to robust cash flow from operations partially offset by a decrease in working capital movement as a result of increase in our receivables. 
Overall, strong cash flow generation has resulted in the net debt-to-EBITDA ratio of only 0.02x at the end of June 2019. 
Let me now hand it back over to Saeed to present our outlook for current year.

headline: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2019
companyname: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC
componenttextpreview: Thanks to Mohamed and Petri. During the remainder of 2019, we are focused on acceleration of our domestic network expansion particularly in Dubai, defending our market share and the growth of our nonfuel business with the expansion of our rewards program
componenttext:
Thanks to Mohamed and Petri. During the remainder of 2019, we are focused on acceleration of our domestic network expansion particularly in Dubai, defending our market share and the growth of our nonfuel business with the expansion of our rewards program to provide a superior experience to our customers. In the Corporate side, we have started sales of 25, 50 and 100 lbs LPG cylinders to customers in Dubai. On nonfuel retail, our expansion will accelerate, and we would continue opening new Géant Express stores and will continue the rollout of our new baking and coffee offering. Finally, cost efficiencies will remain a key pillar and focus throughout the year. 
This now concludes today's presentation, and we are happy to take on any questions that you might have.

componenttext: I had 3 questions, please. The first question I had regarding ADNOC Flex. It's been a year since you've announced premium pricing. I was just wondering how the take-up has been -- what the contribution of that was towards the gross profits in the Retail's fuel business? The second question I had was regarding the rollout of the retail service stations. You've talked about opening 3 new stations and additional 2 new -- additional stations in Dubai this week. I was just wondering of the remaining that you highlight, how many of them are under construction right now? Just looking at what you had presented in the Capital Markets Day, you had these 2 new sites near completion in UAE when you had presented in May. I was just wondering how long does it take, since you have -- [ your decision ] , to completion? And finally, regarding CapEx. I was just wondering, of the remaining CapEx that you have, how much of this is directly catered to the expansion plan? Should -- if there is a rollover for next year, I was just wondering to check how much of the CapEx associated with the retail stations is in your $300 million plan?

headline: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2019
companyname: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC
componenttextpreview: Let's start it from SIPI. Couple of questions from my end. First to start with -- in terms of the fuel Retail business. Just seems that you're opening new stations but just looking at the throughput per station, it's down 11% year-over-year in Q2, it was
componenttext: Let's start it from SIPI. Couple of questions from my end. First to start with -- in terms of the fuel Retail business. Just seems that you're opening new stations but just looking at the throughput per station, it's down 11% year-over-year in Q2, it was down around 9% year-over-year in Q1 2019. I'm was just trying to get the color that -- I mean the throughput per station is not stabilizing and it's still negative. So I just want to hear your thoughts on that. And I mean maybe you can elaborate more that as you open maybe more stations in Dubai, less cannibalization, higher throughput, so any color on how we're moving into H2 in terms of throughput per station would be helpful. And if you can also give us some detail on how then the stations in Dubai have been faring? At least the ones that you've opened 6 to 9 months ago. So that's my first question. My second question is on the ADNOC Flex. Just looking at the press releases overall, it seems that you've waived the Flex in July for everyone and for a couple of customers in August. I mean I just -- I don't know, correct me if I'm wrong, it just seems to be counterintuitive to push out Flex during the summer months where you should expect seasonality at least to drive penetration up. So I just want to understand what's the rationale behind that? And we're just still hearing the 15% to 20% penetration since the beginning of the year. I mean is it taking much more time? I mean is there any change in terms of the focus or how you're approaching Flex, especially that with expansions in Dubai, my guess is that you wouldn't be rolling out Flex because your competition is not charging [ for premium ] services? I'll just leave it there and maybe if I get the chance, I'll ask more. And just one follow-up. Can we get a breakdown of the Retail revenue between fuel and nonfuel? Just for us to get a better understanding on how this gross margin is doing primarily on the C-stores, which is an area that you have been executing well. I'll leave it there.

headline: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2019
companyname: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC
componenttextpreview: Taher, this is Athmane. So we're going -- so the 4 questions. So first of all, on the split of revenues and gross profit, we don't give it. We'll not provide these numbers. But you have the performance of the C-stores in the release actually, and you have
componenttext: Taher, this is Athmane. So we're going -- so the 4 questions. So first of all, on the split of revenues and gross profit, we don't give it. We'll not provide these numbers. But you have the performance of the C-stores in the release actually, and you have, yes, the revenues on Page 10. You have the store revenues end of H1, $107 million with gross profit of $32 million, which brings, if I'm correct, 30% gross margin plus 100 basis point versus last year. So this is for the, I would say, nonfuel performance because nonfuel is mainly the convenience stores as you know. Regarding your question on the throughput per station. So throughput per station is total volume divided by the total of stations that we have. As you know, the retail volumes are down 4.9% year-on-year and the number of stations are up 4.4%, which gives you the 10% decline in the throughput per station. Then I will hand over to Mohamed on the performance of the Dubai stations. But what we expect in a nutshell is in the second half with the new stations in Dubai, where we'll have additional volume, higher market share, that the volumes will be higher than what we have in the first half.

Very good. Thanks a bunch. So as Athmane has mentioned, by the end of the second quarter, we had 4 stations operating in Dubai. And as we speak, just this past week, we opened up 2 additional stations again in Dubai. As far as the performance of these stations, it's very encouraging. Average volume per site in these stations in Dubai is higher than the average volume per site, which is close to about 20 million to 25 million liters per station per year in our other stations in Abu Dhabi and the Northern Emirates. So specifically as far as volumes go by regions, we don't disclose this for competition reasons.

headline: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2019
companyname: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC
componenttextpreview: So thanks a bunch. The 15% to 20% penetration is still applicable. What's encouraging is that compared to first quarter 2019, our retail volumes in the second quarter have been slightly up. So as you alluded to, we've launched promotions such as good morn
componenttext: So thanks a bunch. The 15% to 20% penetration is still applicable. What's encouraging is that compared to first quarter 2019, our retail volumes in the second quarter have been slightly up. So as you alluded to, we've launched promotions such as good morning UAE, that was one. And Fuel Up and Fly Off, that was the second one. These promotions, the intent there was to improve our loyal customer base. So we're also working in parallel on an enhanced rewards program as well as a seamless payment system all in order to provide a superior customer experience. Now this is where our current promotion, the 11 to 5 campaign that you alluded to. Month 1 was to encourage sign-ups, all customers pulling up to the premium service stations were offered the service for free. But month 2, our intern staff are pushed to get people to sign up for the digital rewards program that we are planning to roll out during Q3. The idea was to encourage our customers more strongly to remove it from our customers who were not signing up for the program. Hence, it is no longer free to a certain segment of the customers and it continues to be free for those who are signing up for the ADNOC Wallet, that's basically our digital platform. But again, the idea is to drive our customers to move into our loyalty scheme. More details of that will be provided shortly, but we are designing in the phase -- final phases of designing an ADNOC rewards program. And all of our moves are calculated to promote ADNOC rewards program. Okay. As far as the summer promotion, the Hello Summer, third quarter of 2019, this has again encouraged our customers to adopt our digital platform, which allows us, our marketing initiatives, to lay the groundwork for the upcoming rewards program. Again, all of it is towards providing a superior experience to our customers. Now what do we expect out of this digital platform? Simple, create customer stickiness, as in once they are signed up, we incentivize their constant return and ultimate loyalty to ADNOC Distribution. We expect this to improve the convenience store as well as the Allied Services Wallet spend. The way the rewards program is being designed, it will incentivize fuel premiumization, moving up from 95 to 98 for instance as well as an overall uplift in volumes. This also complements the expansion [ at the moment, ] both in Dubai as well as the Northern Emirates, which is where true organic growth in terms of volumes will come from. In addition to all this, we continue to work on overhauling our total customer experience. We have a vision that is to be the best-in-class fuel and nonfuel retailer, and we're making very, very good strides against that.

headline: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2019
companyname: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC
componenttextpreview: So yes. After -- just as stated, the impairment losses are separately presented in our profit and loss statement and the quantification was USD 7.8 million. In terms of distribution and administrative expenses, we also have a line item of others. This is
componenttext: So yes. After -- just as stated, the impairment losses are separately presented in our profit and loss statement and the quantification was USD 7.8 million. In terms of distribution and administrative expenses, we also have a line item of others. This is a line item that [ covers ] various [ headings ] like rent for offices, consultancy costs, bank charges, cleaning service stations, entertainment, painting, stationary, et cetera, et cetera. Looking at Q1 '19, there was actually reported negative figure, which was heavily driven by reversal of prior year accruals that we had booked in 2018. So we have been, in other words, very conservative last year. Now that we are executing our OpEx efficiency savings program, we've identified excessive provisions made earlier and they have been reversed fully evidencing the good progress that we have in our OpEx efficiencies. Q2, we have included sort of an excessive business development and consultancy costs that we treat as one-off costs. So then it comes to the like-for-like savings discussed earlier, the $36 million overall for the first half, this is the real underlying comparison of our cost efficiency program and progress.

componenttextpreview: Okay. So first of all, we go through the -- our dividend policy. So we told the market at the Capital Market Day that we're going to -- that the Board has agreed to increase the dividend by 63% versus last year's $650 million to be paid for 2019. And in a
componenttext: Okay. So first of all, we go through the -- our dividend policy. So we told the market at the Capital Market Day that we're going to -- that the Board has agreed to increase the dividend by 63% versus last year's $650 million to be paid for 2019. And in accordance with our new dividend policy, we expect to pay half of the fiscal 2019 dividend in the form of an interim dividend payments of $325 million in October 2019 subject to the discussion of our Board of Directors. So we have one payment in October and one payment in April of the following year. This is the dividend policy.

componenttextpreview: Sorry, the nonfuel business. So the nonfuel business. Okay. So nonfuel business, as you were mentioning, the performance has been impressive, you're right, double-digit growth in revenues and profit, higher gross profit margin, higher basket size, mainly
componenttext: Sorry, the nonfuel business. So the nonfuel business. Okay. So nonfuel business, as you were mentioning, the performance has been impressive, you're right, double-digit growth in revenues and profit, higher gross profit margin, higher basket size, mainly driven by the convenience stores when we had this revitalization program, new assortments that have been driving the revenues and the profit. So we -- if we benchmark ourselves versus the competitors, what we know is that the other retailers have been experiencing difficult times. We are talking about low single-digit decline for our peers. What we can tell you is that we come from a very low base. We have been saying this since the IPO for the past 18 months, we have been increasing our basket size by double to -- and single digit for this year. What we expect is growth going forward with the forthcoming revitalization of our C-stores. If you take now broader view on the contribution of the nonfuel business, which is today just below 10%, and you take the international benchmark, we are [ talking ] about more [ than ] 30% to 50% of the profit [ of ]  our peers. So obviously, we will not reach the 50% because our margins are much higher in the fuel business given our guaranteed margins versus our peers. But we see a clear improvement in terms of the contribution of that nonfuel business and this is where we are focusing with the new stations, with a new look and feel and this is where the growth will come from. You want to add anything, Mohamed, on the C-store perhaps and value proposition?

componenttextpreview: If you look -- we do not give guidance for the next 5 years, but for sure, we are expecting a double digit in the coming years for our nonfuel business. So then you can run the numbers and you will see that obviously in the -- in 3 to 5 years, the contrib
componenttext: If you look -- we do not give guidance for the next 5 years, but for sure, we are expecting a double digit in the coming years for our nonfuel business. So then you can run the numbers and you will see that obviously in the -- in 3 to 5 years, the contribution of the nonfuel business would be much higher than what you have today. And this is what we are [ playing ] . This is the aim that we have, it's really to increase the nonfuel business. We are the largest fuel retail player, I'm talking largest convenience store player in the UAE. And this is [ where is the site for ] ADNOC Distribution.

headline: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2019
companyname: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC
componenttextpreview: Indeed, Athmane. So just to add on to that. What we've learned from the promotions that the company has run is we've picked up lots and lots of useful information about our customers. One piece of it, they like to be rewarded, they like to be -- for their
componenttext: Indeed, Athmane. So just to add on to that. What we've learned from the promotions that the company has run is we've picked up lots and lots of useful information about our customers. One piece of it, they like to be rewarded, they like to be -- for their loyalty to ADNOC Distribution. Two, we also learned that the 14 of our stores, which are Géant stores, experienced such an uplift in sales and those are really starting to come through now. H1 2019, both quarters, first quarter and second quarter, as I've stated 26.7% year-on-year first half in terms of sales revenue. Profit -- gross profit increasing as well. Basket size increasing as well. What that tells me is the revitalization program, the uplift in the stores, the category management, better category management in introducing fresh foods and the grab-and-go concept. These initiatives are really starting to resonate with our customers. So I'm really excited. At present, we have 14 Géant stores, but the convenience store revitalization that we're going to do, which is part of our 2019 plan and then continues into 2020, the Oasis stores of course, not the Géant, stores but these are now Oasis stores that are going to be revamped get a new look and feel and the overall customer experience will improve significantly. Very excited about what kind of numbers we're going to report back on second half of 2019, but certainly, 2020 as well. So what's important is the initiatives we're -- we've undertaken. We already know from having tested the 14 stores as well as from the loyalty programs and the summer promotions, we're doing initiatives which resonate with our customers. So once again, very positive about what's going to happen second half of the year but also what numbers -- what the numbers tell us in 2020.

componenttextpreview: Yes. So this is a question, I believe, related to the gross profit by segment, Slide #13. So keep in mind that our operating model is twofold. We provide fuel sales only to our strategic customers, civil aviation airlines are not our [ strategic ] custome
componenttext: Yes. So this is a question, I believe, related to the gross profit by segment, Slide #13. So keep in mind that our operating model is twofold. We provide fuel sales only to our strategic customers, civil aviation airlines are not our [ strategic ] customers. What we do is only provide -- [ operating into ] plane refueling services at multiple airports here in UAE. And this is an illustration of our cost efficiencies. Our costs actually have come down, including in the area of Aviation services, and that is effectively [ reducing ] the recovery together plus 8% reported margin that we had on top of these services. However, the impact at EBITDA level is of course relatively marginal because that's where we capture the OpEx savings offsetting the reduced revenue that we get from the services.

componenttext: Okay. Okay. First of all, as far as the overall economy, we're starting to see some green shoots there with an increase in Corporate volumes. Based on our experience, it's a good indication, it's a good [ lagging ] indication of how the macroeconomic conditions are developing. So having said that, on top of our expansion that we've explained over the course of the call, I fully expect low single-digit year-on-year growth for the second half of 2019 to combine that with, again, market expansion but as well as our full focus, this customer centricity approach that we're taking out to reward our customers through our loyalty scheme. All said and done, expecting good solid single-digit year-on-year growth for the second half of 2019.

componenttextpreview: Just one follow-up question on the C-store, if I may. I'm just doing some numbers and clearly, you've managed to improve the conversion in terms of dollars per 1,000 liters to around $50 in H1 '19. Can we just get color which is -- I mean on a quarterly b
componenttext: Just one follow-up question on the C-store, if I may. I'm just doing some numbers and clearly, you've managed to improve the conversion in terms of dollars per 1,000 liters to around $50 in H1 '19. Can we just get color which is -- I mean on a quarterly basis Q2 is like 23% year-over-year, which is very solid. Can we just get more color on maybe some [ trends ] in terms of when you revitalize the store. And clearly, you understand that you've manage to revitalize more than 50% of the network, how much of an uplift are you seeing in basket size and convergence ratios? This the first part of the question. And the second part, how different is it in terms of conversion between a normal ADNOC Oasis C-store, which was just revitalized, and the Géant, which is the 14 stores that you have, which apparently are doing very well, and recently, the new grab-and-go [ just ] fresh bakery? If you can just put things in perspective with some numbers on that, that would be very helpful.

headline: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2019
companyname: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC
componenttextpreview: Yes. Okay. I will try to not disappoint you, Taher. So just on the nonfuel business and the convenience stores. So your first question was what is the impact of revitalizing the C-store prior and after in terms of revenues margin. So obviously, we are see
componenttext: Yes. Okay. I will try to not disappoint you, Taher. So just on the nonfuel business and the convenience stores. So your first question was what is the impact of revitalizing the C-store prior and after in terms of revenues margin. So obviously, we are seeing in the C-store where we had completely changed the look and feel, the assortment, all the products, et cetera, the material increase in our revenues and the profit. So this is the answer. Two, performance, Oasis versus just Géant, we said earlier in Q1 and the Capital Market Day that the Géant stores have a higher profitability because we are using the knowledge of the Géant Group in terms of category management and how we organize the C-stores. But our Oasis stores, which account today for 90% of our convenience stores, we have brought new capabilities, people who are expert in the convenience stores, people coming from large retailer and working on the revitalization of the core business of the C-store, which is Oasis. So we expect good results coming from Oasis because that we have, I would say, revitalizing completely the C-stores. And the upside is, I would say, much higher than what you would have for a store that we have with Géant, obviously. Does it answer your question?

componenttext: Okay. Well, thank you. Thank you all for being here with us today. Just want to reiterate and -- our strategy going forward for this year and also 2020. headline: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2019
companyname: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning and good afternoon, everyone. This is Faisal Azmeh of Goldman Sachs and I'd like to welcome you all to ADNOC Distribution's 2019 Second Quarter Results Conference Call. It is my pleasure to host the company's executive management t
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning and good afternoon, everyone. This is Faisal Azmeh of Goldman Sachs and I'd like to welcome you all to ADNOC Distribution's 2019 Second Quarter Results Conference Call. It is my pleasure to host the company's executive management team today. The call will start with management's comments on the quarter and the first half, followed by a Q&A session. 
Without further delay, I'll hand it over now to Athmane Benzerroug, the Chief Investor Relations Officer of ADNOC.

headline: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2019
companyname: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC
componenttextpreview: Yes. Hi, everyone. Good morning and good afternoon. This is Athmane Benzerroug. So I'm pleased to welcome this afternoon Saeed Mubarak Al Rashdi, our Chief Executive Officer; Mohamed Al Hashimi, our new Chief Operating Officer; and Petri Pentti, our Chief
componenttext:
Yes. Hi, everyone. Good morning and good afternoon. This is Athmane Benzerroug. So I'm pleased to welcome this afternoon Saeed Mubarak Al Rashdi, our Chief Executive Officer; Mohamed Al Hashimi, our new Chief Operating Officer; and Petri Pentti, our Chief Financial Officer. The objective of the call is to take you through our second quarter and first half results for 2019. 
We will start with a brief update on our strategy. We will then provide details on the financial performance of the second quarter and the first half of 2019, and finally, move on to the outlook for 2019 and beyond. So we will then answer any questions you might have at the end of this presentation. 
Before handing over to -- the call to Saeed, please allow me to reiterate our cautionary statement regarding forward-looking statements. So this presentation includes forward-looking statements relating to our business, important factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from our expectations [ audited ] in the international offering memorandum related to our IPO and in other investor communications, all of which are available on our website. So I direct everyone to our website to read the full text of this disclaimer and these other materials. 
I now hand it over to Saeed, who will start by presenting the key highlights of the first half.

headline: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2019
companyname: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Athmane, and good morning and good afternoon, everyone. Thank you for joining us today. Please allow me to start first by introducing Mohamed Al Hashimi, our new Chief Operating Officer, who has joined our leadership team to focus on execution
componenttext:
Thank you, Athmane, and good morning and good afternoon, everyone. Thank you for joining us today. Please allow me to start first by introducing Mohamed Al Hashimi, our new Chief Operating Officer, who has joined our leadership team to focus on execution of the company's ambitious growth strategy. 
Mohamed is replacing John Carey, who has recently elected to step down as Deputy CEO, but he will continue in an advisory capacity for the time being. John joined us at a time of our IPO and has provided an excellent [ concept ] and leadership to our business as we successfully completed our listing on Abu Dhabi Securities Exchange. 
I would like to place on record my thanks to John for his dedicated efforts during an important period of the company's growth and evolution. 
Before we go into the first half highlights, I would like to reiterate that safety remains a core value to our business. We continue to enhance and invest in safety solutions. 
So in terms of financial performance, we have delivered a 2.8% increase in EBITDA to USD 404 million in the first of 2019 versus the same period in 2018. Excluding inventory gains, EBITDA grew by 11% to USD 371 million in the first half of 2019, and that is mainly driven by continued cost efficiency improvements across the business and better corporate and nonfuel performance. 
We have also shown continued momentum with the first half of 2019 EBITDA margin reaching 14.4%, up from the 13.2% during the same period last year. We also made significant progress in our cost savings with OpEx of USD 36 million on like-to-like basis in the first half of 2019. 
During the first half, we added 3 new service stations and 12 new convenience stores to our current footprint. We are on track to deliver on our transformation initiative and growth plans. During the remainder of 2019, we are focused on the acceleration of our domestic growth network expansion particularly in Dubai and the growth of our own nonfuel business to provide superior experience to our customers. We also continue to explore opportunities to grow internationally, including Saudi Arabia and markets that we deliver against our investment criteria of 13% IRR threshold. 
Cost efficiencies also remain a core focus, and we will continue to improve our OpEx and CapEx plans. Finally, we try to continue to deliver strong and sustainable growth while providing attractive returns to our shareholders. This is evidenced by the announcement on April of a significant increase to our dividend confirming our confidence in our growth strategy and future cash flow generation. 
I will now let Mohamed give you an update and more color on our strategy execution.

headline: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2019
companyname: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you, Saeed. I am pleased that on my first call with you, we can show solid progress on our growth strategy. So I met many of you around the time of the IPO back in 2017 as well as our recent Capital Markets Day, both in London and New York. S
componenttext:
Great. Thank you, Saeed. I am pleased that on my first call with you, we can show solid progress on our growth strategy. So I met many of you around the time of the IPO back in 2017 as well as our recent Capital Markets Day, both in London and New York. So just to add a bit of background, I was closely involved in the ADNOC Distribution's IPO process, and I've delivered large-scale projects, transactions and partnerships as Senior Vice President of [ Group's ] Strategic Investments for the ADNOC Group. 
More recently, I was also adviser to the ADNOC Distribution executive committee. This has helped provide me with in-depth knowledge of the ADNOC Distribution business, and more importantly, its plans for growth. ADNOC Distribution remains focused on delivering its ambitious strategy as well as building long-term shareholder value through the next phase of our growth. Now we've delivered strong first half year results with more to come. 
So let me begin by giving you an update on the Retail fuel segment, our first strategic pillar. 
During the Capital Markets Day, we presented a refreshed investment proposition, and we announced key initiatives to be implemented during the course of 2019 and beyond. So in line with earlier guidance that most of our new stations will open towards the end of 2019, I'm pleased to announce that we remain on track to open 20 to 30 new stations across the UAE this year, and we are clearly focused on accelerating our footprint in Dubai. 
So in the first half alone, we've opened 3 new stations in UAE and also pleased to announce that we have just opened 2 additional stations in Dubai this week leading to a total of 6 service stations currently operating in Dubai. So our domestic network expansion track -- target is on track, and we've already identified an in-advance stage of execution on 18 new sites. 
Secondly, on Saudi Arabia, we will provide more color on our expansion plans and operating model during our Q3 results announcement. Our focus at present remains on our home market. So in the second quarter, we launched a number of marketing promotions to address the anticipated lower retail fuel volumes, and we've encouraged our customers to register in our Wallet mobile application towards the enhancement of our overall customer experience. We were pleased to see encouraging results with fuel retail volumes stable in second quarter of 2019 compared to the first quarter of 2019. 
On the Corporate segment, we've achieved 5.5% year-on-year growth in volumes in the first half of 2019. Now this was driven by increased sales of LPG, lubricants as well as base oil. Now we expect this trend in corporate volumes to continue during 2019 following significant government investments in the economy. 
In first half of 2019, we also entered the commercial 100 lb cylinder market in Dubai. Now we've chosen to enter the Dubai LPG market by partnering with established distributors, which now gives us a quick route to market and an effective entry. 
So moving on to nonfuel retail. First half of 2019, we opened 12 new convenience stores across the UAE. Now 10 of these were opened in the second quarter of 2019 at our existing retail sites. At the end of first half 2019, we had a total of 262 convenience stores. Now 14 of these are Géant stores. Our -- the company's convenience stores revitalization programs, which I alluded to yesterday, also offers our customers a significantly improved shopping experience. Pleased to say that this is on track and is contributing to positive convenience store performance. 
Improvements were also seen in gross margins and an overall uplift in the average basket size in the first half of 2019 compared to the first half of 2018. Sales revenue from convenience stores was up by 26.7% year-on-year in first half of 2019. Gross profit increased by 28.9% and the average convenience store basket size increased by 6.8% year-on-year in first half 2019. 
Now this has been achieved through various factors. Improving the look and feel of our stores, better category management adapting to the demand of our customers, and the introduction of fresh grab-and-go concept, positive performance of Géant stores, rewards issued to our customers under the Flex initiative, and an improved customer value proposition through the introduction of promotions supported by in-store marketing. 
So at the end of the second quarter 2019, ADNOC Flex Premium penetration was 15% to 20% on average, in line with what we have seen in the first quarter. 
Now to sum up, we are going to continue our expansion, and we remain absolutely committed to our convenience store revitalization program in order to further improve our overall customer experience. 
So finally, let me give you an update on our cost efficiency initiative, the third pillar of our strategic plan. We have made significant progress in rationalizing our cash OpEx. Pleased to say that we've achieved $36 million in like-for-like OpEx savings in the first half of 2019 mainly driven by cost-optimization initiatives. Now we are on track to achieve around $50 million of OpEx savings in 2019 on a like-for-like basis. 
In terms of capital expenditure, so far we've spent $38 million of CapEx in the first half of 2019. As I've stated, we remain focused on defining a network expansion allocation in the first half of 2019. As also mentioned earlier, our network rollout is scheduled for operational deployment towards the end of this year. In line with that, we expect to accelerate our capital expenditure in the second half of 2019. We maintained our guidance on capital expenditure for the year of up to $300 million to boost our network expansion in the UAE and internationally with 20 to 30 new sites in the UAE, primarily in Dubai to accelerate our convenience store expansion, to continue to significantly improve our customer experience and to invest in our IT infrastructure and digital initiatives. 
So in addition to the savings we have achieved so far, we see more room to achieve further capital expenditure efficiency in building new sites. 
So at this point, I will now hand over to Petri to present the highlights of our financial performance.

headline: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2019
companyname: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC
componenttextpreview: Many thanks, Mohamed, and good morning, good afternoon, everyone. So as Mohamed mentioned, the implementation of our initiatives have resulted in the achievement of positive results in the first half despite the decrease in overall fuel volumes. The first
componenttext:
Many thanks, Mohamed, and good morning, good afternoon, everyone. So as Mohamed mentioned, the implementation of our initiatives have resulted in the achievement of positive results in the first half despite the decrease in overall fuel volumes. The first half revenues reached USD 2.8 billion, down by 6.3% when compared to the first half of 2018. This decline in revenues was mainly driven by lower fuel volumes sold as well as lower pump average prices. To use an example, our 95 gasoline octane average pump prices for the first half of  2019 were 8.5% below first half 2018. Having said that, we saw a continuous improvement in our convenience stores business with an increase in revenues by 26.7% in the first half to USD 107 million driven by the revitalization program that Mohamed was talking about. 
We do see [ green shoot ] in our Corporate business. Volumes are up 5.5% year-on-year driven by increase in LPG and lubricant sales following significant government investments in the UAE economy. Our gross profit reached USD 675 million, down 5% compared to the previous year. The decrease is mainly due to the lower inventory gains in the first half, $33 million versus $58 million in 2018 in our Retail business. 
Meanwhile, we achieved a 10% increase in our nonfuel gross profit mainly coming from the convenience stores in the first half compared to the 2018 period, and this is driven by the improved category management and our fuel rewards program. 
Our gross profit margin has also shown continued momentum and is still at an industrial-leading level, reaching 24.1% in the first half of 2019, up from 23.8% last year. And this is driven by lower revenue due to lower pump prices compared with the secured minimum retail margin as per the Ministry of Energy regulations here in UAE. 
Finally, our total EBITDA for the first half reached $404 million, representing an increase of 2.8% year-on-year driven by the continued cost efficiencies, growth in the corporate segment and more dynamic product pricing. We've made significant progress in rationalizing our OpEx and have [ stabilized achieving ] USD 36 million in like-for-like OpEx savings during the first half driven by the cost optimization initiatives. Our cash OpEx declined by 16.5% in the first half compared to first half last year, reaching $282 million. Excluding the inventory gains of $33 million for Q2 '19 and $58 million for the first half 2018, the underlying EBITDA grew by 11% year-on-year in the first half, once again, driven by the cost efficiency improvements across the whole business. 
Finally, we generated strong free cash flow measured as EBITDA minus CapEx. Free cash flow is up by 21% year-on-year to $366 million in the first half driven by also higher EBITDA and lower CapEx. 
Overall, fuel sales volumes were down in first half by 1.7% driven by 3.5% decrease in fuel rate volumes mainly due to increased competition as well as the impact of the longer public holiday in second quarter 2019 compared to the same period last year. 
On the Corporate segment side, volumes increased by 5.5% first half driven by the higher sales of the LPG, lubricant and base oil as stated earlier. And finally, our Aviation segment volumes sold to the strategic customers were marginally up in the first half 2019. 
Looking at the gross profit performance by segment. Gross profit for nonfuel retail mainly convenience stores increased by 10% year-on-year in the first half. This is reflecting our diversification strategy towards nonfuel retail and implementation of the new initiatives to improve customer experience, including a much more focused stores revitalization program as well as the positive contribution from our fuel rewards program. Our fuel retail gross profit decreased in the first half by 8.7% year-on-year. This is driven by the decrease in fuel retail volumes as well as lower inventory gains as stated earlier in the first half 2019. In the Corporate segment, gross profit has increased in the first half by 12.3% and margin has increased from 18.5% to 19.8% on the back of the increase in volumes, better inventory management as well as more dynamic product pricing. 
And finally, our Aviation gross profit has decreased in the first half by 8.7% year-on-year. This is driven by lower Aviation services and civil aviation OpEx recovery under the arrangement we have with the parent company, ADNOC. 
Moving on to EBITDA. Total EBITDA for first half reached $404 million. This is an increase of 2.8% year-on-year. As stated earlier, continued cost efficiencies as well as Corporate segment performance is contributing to this increase together with higher Corporate volumes.
Our fuel and nonfuel retail company EBITDA increased by 0.3% and Corporate segment by 29.4% year-on-year in the first half. Q2 2019 EBITDA growth was driven by Retail segment with an increase in EBITDA margins driven by cost efficiencies despite the lower volumes. Q2 '19 Corporate EBITDA was flat due to lower diesel margins partially offset by cost efficiencies and higher volumes. 
And finally, Aviation EBITDA was flat due to stable volumes and cost efficiencies partially offset by lower aviation services revenue. Excluding the inventory gains realized in the second quarter '19 and during the first half 2018, $33 million and $58 million, respectively, underlying EBITDA increased year-on-year by 11% during the first half. 
And finally, a few comments on our cash position and cash flow during the first half. Net cash generated from operating activities has increased mainly due to robust cash flow from operations partially offset by a decrease in working capital movement as a result of increase in our receivables. 
Overall, strong cash flow generation has resulted in the net debt-to-EBITDA ratio of only 0.02x at the end of June 2019. 
Let me now hand it back over to Saeed to present our outlook for current year.

headline: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2019
companyname: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC
componenttextpreview: Thanks to Mohamed and Petri. During the remainder of 2019, we are focused on acceleration of our domestic network expansion particularly in Dubai, defending our market share and the growth of our nonfuel business with the expansion of our rewards program
componenttext:
Thanks to Mohamed and Petri. During the remainder of 2019, we are focused on acceleration of our domestic network expansion particularly in Dubai, defending our market share and the growth of our nonfuel business with the expansion of our rewards program to provide a superior experience to our customers. In the Corporate side, we have started sales of 25, 50 and 100 lbs LPG cylinders to customers in Dubai. On nonfuel retail, our expansion will accelerate, and we would continue opening new Géant Express stores and will continue the rollout of our new baking and coffee offering. Finally, cost efficiencies will remain a key pillar and focus throughout the year. 
This now concludes today's presentation, and we are happy to take on any questions that you might have.

componenttext: I had 3 questions, please. The first question I had regarding ADNOC Flex. It's been a year since you've announced premium pricing. I was just wondering how the take-up has been -- what the contribution of that was towards the gross profits in the Retail's fuel business? The second question I had was regarding the rollout of the retail service stations. You've talked about opening 3 new stations and additional 2 new -- additional stations in Dubai this week. I was just wondering off the remaining that you highlight, how many of them are under construction right now? Just looking at what you had presented in the Capital Markets Day, you had these 2 new sites near completion in UAE when you had presented in May. I was just wondering how long does it take, since you have -- [ your decision ] , to completion? And finally, regarding CapEx. I was just wondering, of the remaining CapEx that you have, how much of this is directly catered to the expansion plan? Should -- if there is a rollover for next year, I was just wondering to check how much of the CapEx associated with the retail stations is in your $300 million plan?

headline: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2019
companyname: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC
componenttextpreview: Let's start it from SIPI. Couple of questions from my end. First to start with -- in terms of the fuel Retail business. Just seems that you're opening new stations but just looking at the throughput per station, it's down 11% year-over-year in Q2, it was
componenttext: Let's start it from SIPI. Couple of questions from my end. First to start with -- in terms of the fuel Retail business. Just seems that you're opening new stations but just looking at the throughput per station, it's down 11% year-over-year in Q2, it was down around 9% year-over-year in Q1 2019. I'm was just trying to get the color that -- I mean the throughput per station is not stabilizing and it's still negative. So I just want to hear your thoughts on that. And I mean maybe you can elaborate more that as you open maybe more stations in Dubai, less cannibalization, higher throughput, so any color on how we're moving into H2 in terms of throughput per station would be helpful. And if you can also give us some detail on how then the stations in Dubai have been faring? At least the ones that you've opened 6 to 9 months ago. So that's my first question. My second question is on the ADNOC Flex. Just looking at the press releases overall, it seems that you've waived the Flex in July for everyone and for a couple of customers in August. I mean I just -- I don't know, correct me if I'm wrong, it just seems to be counterintuitive to push out Flex during the summer months where you should expect seasonality at least to drive penetration up. So I just want to understand what's the rationale behind that? And we're just still hearing the 15% to 20% penetration since the beginning of the year. I mean is it taking much more time? I mean is there any change in terms of the focus or how you're approaching Flex, especially that with expansions in Dubai, my guess is that you wouldn't be rolling out Flex because your competition is not charging [ for premium ] services? I'll just leave it there and maybe if I get the chance, I'll ask more. And just one follow-up. Can we get a breakdown of the Retail revenue between fuel and nonfuel? Just for us to get a better understanding on how this gross margin is doing primarily on the C-stores, which is an area that you have been executing well. I'll leave it there.

headline: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2019
companyname: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC
componenttextpreview: Taher, this is Athmane. So we're going -- so the 4 questions. So first of all, on the split of revenues and gross profit, we don't give it. We'll not provide these numbers. But you have the performance of the C-stores in the release actually, and you have
componenttext: Taher, this is Athmane. So we're going -- so the 4 questions. So first of all, on the split of revenues and gross profit, we don't give it. We'll not provide these numbers. But you have the performance of the C-stores in the release actually, and you have, yes, the revenues on Page 10. You have the store revenues end of H1, $107 million with gross profit of $32 million, which brings, if I'm correct, 30% gross margin plus 100 basis point versus last year. So this is for the, I would say, nonfuel performance because nonfuel is mainly the convenience stores as you know. Regarding your question on the throughput per station. So throughput per station is total volume divided by the total of stations that we have. As you know, the retail volumes are down 4.9% year-on-year and the number of stations are up 4.4%, which gives you the 10% decline in the throughput per station. Then I will hand over to Mohamed on the performance of the Dubai stations. But what we expect in a nutshell is in the second half with the new stations in Dubai, where we'll have additional volume, higher market share, that the volumes will be higher than what we have in the first half.

Very good. Thanks a bunch. So as Athmane has mentioned, by the end of the second quarter, we had 4 stations operating in Dubai. And as we speak, just this past week, we opened up 2 additional stations again in Dubai. As far as the performance of these stations, it's very encouraging. Average volume per site in these stations in Dubai is higher than the average volume per site, which is close to about 20 million to 25 million liters per station per year in our other stations in Abu Dhabi and the Northern Emirates. So specifically as far as volumes go by regions, we don't disclose this for competition reasons.

headline: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2019
companyname: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for Distribution PJSC
componenttextpreview: So thanks a bunch. The 15% to 20% penetration is still applicable. What's encouraging is that compared to first quarter 2019, our retail volumes in the second quarter have been slightly up. So as you alluded to, we've launched promotions such as good morn
componenttext: So thanks a bunch. The 15% to 20% penetration is still applicable. What's encouraging is that compared to first quarter 2019, our retail volumes in the second quarter have been slightly up. So as you alluded to, we've launched promotions such as good morning UAE, that was one. And Fuel Up and Fly Off, that was the second one. These promotions, the intent there was to improve our loyal customer base. So we're also working in parallel on an enhanced rewards program as well as a seamless payment system all in order to provide a superior customer experience. Now this is where our current promotion, the 11 to 5 campaign that you alluded to. Month 1 was to encourage sign-ups, all customers pulling up to the premium service stations were offered the service for free. But month 2, our intern staff are pushed to get people to sign up for the digital rewards program that we are planning to roll out during Q3. The idea was to encourage our customers more strongly to remove it from our customers who were not signing up for the program. Hence, it is no longer free to a certain segment of the customers and it continues to be free for those who are signing up for the ADNOC Wallet, that's basically our digital platform. But again, the idea is to drive our customers to move into our loyalty scheme. More details of that will be provided shortly, but we are designing in the phase -- final phases of designing an ADNOC rewards program. And all of our moves are calculated to promote ADNOC rewards program. Okay. As far as the summer promotion, the Hello Summer, third quarter of 2019, this has again encouraged our customers to adopt our digital platform, which allows us, our marketing initiatives, to lay the groundwork for the upcoming rewards program. Again, all of it is towards providing a superior experience to our customers. Now what do we expect out of this digital platform? Simple, create customer stickiness, as in once they are signed up, we incentivize their constant return and ultimate loyalty to ADNOC Distribution. We expect this to improve the convenience store as well as the Allied Services Wallet spend. The way the rewards program is being designed, it will incentivize fuel premiumization, moving up from 95 to 98 for instance as well as an overall uplift in volumes. This also complements the expansion [ at the moment, ] both in Dubai as well as the Northern Emirates, which is where true organic growth in terms of volumes will come from. In addition to all this, we continue to work on overhauling our total customer experience. We have a vision that is to be the best-in-class fuel and nonfuel retailer, and we're making very, very good strides against that.
